text:
The invention of kerosene didn’t happen specifically to replace whale oil. It just happened and people figured out it would be way cheaper than whale oil. Similarly, the light bulb replacing kerosene didn’t happen because they were specifically putting money into replacing kerosene, but because humans developed electricity and realized that it’s even cheaper and more efficient than kerosene. 

His analogies are poor and not well thought out, and he talks about innovation as if its a magical solution. Guess what, we already have been innovating and the technology already exists to stop climate change, and it continues to get better every day

text: He actually makes the analogy pretty well, he just (purposefully) glosses over the actual factors that made the analogy work. Capitalism does not care about the whales, or the environment, or the people living in it: it cares about profit. Kerosene was more profitable (lower cost input than whale hunting, higher degree of regularity in production) than whale oil, so it grew to replace it. Right now, fossil fuels are the most profitable method of producing energy abroad, and until that changes the capitalist system will fail to, and even fight against, the change. They’ve done so for years.
